model.hed: The Easy, No-Stress Way to Make Fresh Pasta
model.promoHed: How to Make Hand-Shaped Pasta Any Night of the Week
model.body:
For as long as I can remember, I've fantasized about living in Italy. Eating pasta all day long, drinking wine all night long, harvesting in the vineyards sometime in between—I want the full Nonna lifestyle. But just because I dream in *Under-the-Tuscan-Sun*-Technicolor doesn't actually make me one of those Italian cooks who roll out handmade pasta without batting a sooty eyelash.

[#article: /articles/55fc4532cb84959337fd4663]||||||

Luckily, Epi's Editorial Assistant Sheela Prakash actually lived that life, spending four months working on a farm in Tuscany after college and then later attending graduate school in the oh-so-dreamy Tuscan hillside village of Bra. Listening to Sheela's stories of making fresh pasta, [incredible honey](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/how-to-cook-with-shop-bake-with-honey-article), and [eating her weight in garlicky pasta salad](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/italian-secret-great-pasta-salad-recipe-article), is almost, sort of, like being there myself.

But the thing that was most surprising? Just how often she still manages to make fresh pasta in her apartment kitchen now that she's back in New York. "If you can toss a few ingredients into a food processor and hit the pulse button a few times, then you can make fresh pasta," she assured me.

Encouraged, I went into the kitchen and started playing with dough. After several batches in the kitchen, I finally created a versatile dough that feels silky smooth in my hands and can easily be shaped into [long "pici" noodles](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-long-pici-pasta-gallery), [orecchiette ears](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-orecchiette-pasta-gallery), or [little cavatelli dumplings](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-cavatelli-pasta-gallery), perfect for anytime my Nonna cravings come calling. 

Here's what I learned after making a few batches in the test kitchen:

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55fc7a06393f29a26aca9195]||||||

+++

##The Food Processor Is Your Friend##
Most fresh pasta recipes (like ones from Italian cookbook legend Marcella Hazan and renowned Italian chef Jenn Louis), are a super-simple combination of [semolina flour](http://www.kingarthurflour.com/shop/items/king-arthur-semolina-flour-3-lb) (a yellow, more coarse wheat flour), all-purpose flour, salt, and water. Good. So the basic recipe is already easy. All I needed to do was make it *even easier.* Louis, who writes in her book [*Pasta By Hand*](http://www.amazon.com/Pasta-Hand-Collection-Regional-Hand-Shaped/dp/1452121885) about using a stand mixer to bring pasta dough together, gave me the idea to try using a food processor. And guess what? It works beautifully.

##Dough Needs to Be Kneaded (at least a little bit)##
The key to great pasta dough is creating a smooth, elastic dough that's not too sticky and not too dry. The key to that perfect texture? Giving your dough a few minutes of kneading time after it comes out of the food processor. Kneading the dough helps form the gluten that gives the pasta that al dente texture. 

[#recipe: /recipes/560013c2d296e7ab46e9db0e]|||
Pasta Dough for Handmade Shapes
|||

##You Don't Need Special Gear to Shape Your Pasta##
Not going to lie, even with my super-smooth pasta dough, I was really intimidated by hand-shaping it. Luckily, Sheela schooled me on some of the easiest shapes, starting with *pici*, which are basically [hand-rolled spaghetti noodles](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-long-pici-pasta-gallery). (If you've ever played around with Play-Doh, it's likely you've made this shape.) Next we tackled [orecchiette](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-orecchiette-pasta-gallery), which really just needs a quick twist of the thumb to make that classic "ear" shape. For [cavatelli](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-cavatelli-pasta-gallery), Sheela showed me how to simply press my fingers into the dough, then drag them across the cutting board to make the hollowed shapes.

The shapes can take a little bit of practice to perfect. But when another batch of easy dough is just minutes away, I can practice all day. Just like Nonna would.

[#gallery: /galleries/55fb063a393f29a26aca8c7a]|||
How to Shape Fresh Orecchiette Pasta
|||

[#gallery: /galleries/55fb2823393f29a26aca8d8a]|||
How to Shape Fresh Long Pici Pasta
|||

[#gallery: /galleries/55fb2349393f29a26aca8d52]|||
How to Shape Fresh Cavatelli Pasta
|||

inline.dek: Five days of pasta intel you can really sink your teeth into (because it's *al dente*).
inline.body:
When we first talked about dedicating a week at Epicurious to pasta (a Pasta Week, if you will), it seemed like a no-brainer. Of *course* we should do a series of stories celebrating pasta. After all, there's no other food we turn to as instinctively and automatically as those Italian noodles. Too tired to cook something fancy? Make some pasta. Need something to eat while watching *The Voice*? Make some pasta. Nothing in the fridge? Two words: [pantry pasta](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/pasta-with-15-minute-garlic-oil-and-anchovy-sauce-56390061). 

But the more we thought about the stuff, the more we realized how deep our pasta habits really run. Sometimes we turn into pasta zombies, mindlessly making the same old sauce week after week. We had a hunch that even when it comes to something as easy as weeknight pasta, there's a lot to learn. 

And learn we did. We learned how to make an [amazingly delicious meat sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fast-easy-pasta-sauces-weeknights-article)—that tastes like it took all day to simmer—in just 15 minutes. We learned how [one simple ingredient](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/top-your-pasta-with-breadcrumbs-article) can transform almost any plate of pasta. And we learned how to make a homemade pasta [without ever messing with dough](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/how-to-make-simple-two-ingredient-fresh-pasta-article).

And that's just the beginning. We're going to share pasta intel every day this week, and we hope you'll do the same. Tag shots of your pasta dinners with #weeknightpasta on Instagram and Twitter, and tell us how you like your pasta. Odds are, we'll like it, too. It's pasta, after all.
inline.seoDescription: An introduction to Epicurious Pasta Week.

fields.title: Pasta with Grilled Tomato and Scallion Sauce

inline.hed: How to Shape Fresh Long Pici Pasta
inline.dek: This Tuscan pasta, which resembles thick spaghetti, is dead simple to make yourself.
inline.promoDek: This Tuscan pasta, which resembles thick spaghetti, is dead simple to make yourself.
inline.promoHed: How to Make Fresh Long Pasta at Home

items.title: Pull Off Some Dough
items.caption: Start by pulling a walnut-sized piece from your ball of [fresh pasta dough](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/the-easy-way-to-make-fresh-pasta-dough-at-home-article). Rewrap the dough tightly in plastic wrap to keep it from drying out.

items.title: Roll Away
items.caption:
On a wooden cutting board or surface, roll out the walnut-sized piece of dough to a long rope, about 1/2-inch thick.
If your dough is sticking to the surface and you're having trouble rolling it out, sprinkle the surface with a little semolina flour. If you find you're having the opposite problem—that the dough is too dry to roll—dampen your hands with a little warm water.

items.title: Cut...
items.caption: Using a [bench scraper](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/bench-scraper-tips-tricks-article) or a sharp knife, cut the pasta rope into 4-inch-long segments.

items.title: Then Just Keep Rolling
items.caption: Roll out each segment into long ropes that are just over 1/8-inch wide.

items.title: Done!
items.caption:
Move your *pici* to a sheet pan or plate, dusted with semolina flour to prevent sticking. Once you've shaped all of your dough, cook it in a large pot of boiling, salted water until al dente, 6-7 minutes. Drain, [toss with sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fast-easy-pasta-sauces-weeknights-article), and then eat! 
You can also freeze the uncooked *pici* to cook later. Just stick the sheet pan or plate in the freezer. Once they're frozen solid, transfer them to an airtight container. They'll keep well for about 2 weeks. To cook, just toss them frozen into the boiling, salted water and add an extra minute or two to the cooking time.

inline.seoTitle: How to Make Fresh Pici Pasta at Home
inline.seoDescription: This Tuscan pasta, which resembles thick spaghetti, is dead simple to make yourself.
inline.socialTitle: How to Make Fresh Pici Pasta at Home
inline.socialDescription: This Tuscan pasta, which resembles thick spaghetti, is dead simple to make yourself.

inline.hed: How to Shape Fresh Orecchiette Pasta
inline.dek: These bite-sized, cup-shaped pasta "ears" couldn't be easier to make.
inline.promoHed: How to Make Orecchiette Pasta From Scratch

items.title: Grab Some Dough
items.caption: Start by pulling a walnut-sized piece from your ball of [fresh pasta dough](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/the-easy-way-to-make-fresh-pasta-dough-at-home-article). Rewrap the dough tightly in plastic wrap to keep it from drying out.

items.title: Start Rolling
items.caption:
On a wooden cutting board or surface, use the palms of your hands to roll out the walnut-sized piece of dough to a 1/2-inch-wide rope.

If your dough is sticking to the surface and you're having trouble rolling it out, sprinkle the surface with a little semolina flour. If you find you're having the opposite problem—that the dough is too dry to roll—dampen your hands with a little water.

items.title: Then Cut
items.caption: Using a [bench scraper](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/bench-scraper-tips-tricks-article) or sharp knife, cut the pasta rope into 1/2-inch pieces.

items.title: Press
items.caption: Next, use your thumb to press down each piece of dough against the work surface, slightly pushing and twisting away from you to form an indented round of dough. (If the dough starts to stick, just dust the work surface with semolina).

items.title: And Push
items.caption: Put the disc (with the indented side down) on the tip of your thumb and use your other hand to gently pull the sides down around the tip of your thumb to deepen the indentation.

items.title: Finish Shaping
items.caption: Turn the pasta cup inside-out around the index finger of your opposite hand. Then use the fingers of your other hand to deepen the cup once again.

items.title: Ta-dah!
items.caption:
Move your orecchiette to a sheet pan or plate that's been dusted with semolina flour to prevent sticking. Once you've shaped all of your dough, cook the orecchiette in a large pot of boiling, salted water until al dente, 5-6 minutes. Drain it, toss with [plenty of sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fast-easy-pasta-sauces-weeknights-article), and enjoy! 

You can also freeze the orecchiette to cook up later. Just stick the sheet pan or plate in the freezer until the pasta is frozen solid, then transfer the pasta to an airtight container. They'll keep well for about 2 weeks. To cook, just toss them frozen into the boiling, salted water and add an extra minute or two to the cooking time.

inline.seoDescription: Step-by-step instructions on how to form this cup-like Italian pasta shape by hand.
inline.socialTitle: How to Make Orecchiette From Scratch
inline.socialDescription: These bite-sized, cup-shaped pasta "ears" couldn't be easier to make.

inline.hed: How to Shape Fresh Cavatelli Pasta
inline.dek: This short pasta is fun to make—and even more fun to eat.
inline.promoHed: How to Make Fresh Cavatelli Pasta. With Your Bare Hands.

items.title: Begin with a Piece of Dough
items.caption: Start by pulling a walnut-sized piece from your ball of [fresh pasta dough](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/the-easy-way-to-make-fresh-pasta-dough-at-home-article). Rewrap the dough tightly in plastic wrap to keep it from drying out.

items.title: Start Rolling
items.caption:
On a wooden cutting board or surface, roll out the walnut-sized piece of dough to a 1/3-inch-wide rope.

If your dough is sticking to the surface and you're having trouble rolling it out, sprinkle the surface with a little semolina flour. If you find you're having the opposite problem—that the dough is too dry to roll—dampen your hands with a little water.

items.title: Cut Into Pieces
items.caption: Using a [bench scraper](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/bench-scraper-tips-tricks-article) or sharp knife, cut the pasta rope into 1 3/4-inch segments.

items.title: Push and Pull
items.caption: Press each piece with your three middle fingers, creating an indentation while you pull the piece toward you against the work surface.

items.title: Lookin' Good
items.caption: The cavatelli pasta should be rounded on the outside, with three distinct indentations on the inside.

items.title: Finished!
items.caption:
Move your cavatelli to a semolina-dusted sheet pan or plate to prevent sticking. Once you've shaped all of your dough, cook the pasta in a large pot of boiling, salted water until al dente, 6-7 minutes. Drain the pasta, [toss it with sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fast-easy-pasta-sauces-weeknights-article), and eat! 

You can also freeze the cavatelli to cook up later. Just stick the sheet pan or plate in the freezer. Once the shapes are frozen solid, transfer them to an airtight container. They'll keep well for about 2 weeks. To cook, just toss them frozen into the boiling, salted water and add an extra minute or two to the cooking time.

inline.seoDescription: Step-by-step instructions on forming this short Italian pasta shape by hand.
inline.socialDescription: This short pasta is fun to make—and even more fun to eat.
